  16. (** Semaphores

  18.   A semaphore is a thread synchronization device that can be used to
  19.   control access to a shared resource.

  21.   Two flavors of semaphores are provided: counting semaphores and
  22.   binary semaphores.

  24.   @since 4.12 *)

  26. (** {2 Counting semaphores} *)

  28. (**
  29.   A counting semaphore is a counter that can be accessed concurrently
  30.   by several threads.  The typical use is to synchronize producers and
  31.   consumers of a resource by counting how many units of the resource
  32.   are available.

  34.   The two basic operations on semaphores are:
  35. - "release" (also called "V", "post", "up", and "signal"), which
  36.   increments the value of the counter.  This corresponds to producing
  37.   one more unit of the shared resource and making it available to others.
  38. - "acquire" (also called "P", "wait", "down", and "pend"), which
  39.   waits until the counter is greater than zero and decrements it.
  40.   This corresponds to consuming one unit of the shared resource.

  42.   @since 4.12 *)

  44. module Counting : sig

  46. type t
  47. (** The type of counting semaphores. *)

  49. val make : int -> t
  50. (** [make n] returns a new counting semaphore, with initial value [n].
  51.     The initial value [n] must be nonnegative.

  53.     @raise Invalid_argument if [n < 0]
  54. *)

  56. val release : t -> unit
  57. (** [release s] increments the value of semaphore [s].
  58.     If other threads are waiting on [s], one of them is restarted.
  59.     If the current value of [s] is equal to [max_int], the value of
  60.     the semaphore is unchanged and a [Sys_error] exception is raised
  61.     to signal overflow.

  63.     @raise Sys_error if the value of the semaphore would overflow [max_int]
  64. *)

  66. val acquire : t -> unit
  67. (** [acquire s] blocks the calling thread until the value of semaphore [s]
  68.     is not zero, then atomically decrements the value of [s] and returns.
  69. *)

  71. val try_acquire : t -> bool
  72. (** [try_acquire s] immediately returns [false] if the value of semaphore [s]
  73.     is zero.  Otherwise, the value of [s] is atomically decremented
  74.     and [try_acquire s] returns [true].
  75. *)

  77. val get_value : t -> int
  78. (** [get_value s] returns the current value of semaphore [s].
  79.     The current value can be modified at any time by concurrent
  80.     {!release} and {!acquire} operations.  Hence, the [get_value]
  81.     operation is racy, and its result should only be used for debugging
  82.     or informational messages.
  83. *)

  85. end

  87. (** {2 Binary semaphores} *)

  89. (** Binary semaphores are a variant of counting semaphores
  90.     where semaphores can only take two values, 0 and 1.

  92.     A binary semaphore can be used to control access to a single
  93.     shared resource, with value 1 meaning "resource is available" and
  94.     value 0 meaning "resource is unavailable".

  96.     The "release" operation of a binary semaphore sets its value to 1,
  97.     and "acquire" waits until the value is 1 and sets it to 0.

  99.     A binary semaphore can be used instead of a mutex (see module
  100.     {!Mutex}) when the mutex discipline (of unlocking the mutex from the
  101.     thread that locked it) is too restrictive.  The "acquire" operation
  102.     corresponds to locking the mutex, and the "release" operation to
  103.     unlocking it, but "release" can be performed in a thread different
  104.     than the one that performed the "acquire".  Likewise, it is safe
  105.     to release a binary semaphore that is already available.

  107.     @since 4.12
  108. *)

  110. module Binary : sig

  112. type t
  113. (** The type of binary semaphores. *)

  115. val make : bool -> t
  116. (** [make b] returns a new binary semaphore.
  117.     If [b] is [true], the initial value of the semaphore is 1, meaning
  118.     "available".  If [b] is [false], the initial value of the
  119.     semaphore is 0, meaning "unavailable".
  120. *)

  122. val release : t -> unit
  123. (** [release s] sets the value of semaphore [s] to 1, putting it in the
  124.     "available" state.  If other threads are waiting on [s], one of them is
  125.     restarted.
  126. *)

  128. val acquire : t -> unit
  129. (** [acquire s] blocks the calling thread until the semaphore [s]
  130.     has value 1 (is available), then atomically sets it to 0
  131.     and returns.
  132. *)

  134. val try_acquire : t -> bool
  135. (** [try_acquire s] immediately returns [false] if the semaphore [s]
  136.     has value 0.  If [s] has value 1, its value is atomically set to 0
  137.     and [try_acquire s] returns [true].
  138. *)

  140. end
